title: Curriculum Framework: From Vibes to Variables
text: Weeks 1-3: Foundation & Orientation - Students understand research structured storytelling - Set reproducible workflow tools (R/RStudio/Quarto/Git) - Analyze complete example study see end goal Weeks 4-7: Conceptual Framework - Learn scientific method research ethics - Conduct literature review theoretical framing - Draft project prospectus (â€™ll study semester) Weeks 8-11: Data Collection & Coding - Operationalize â€œvibesâ€ measurable variables - Build codebook reliability checks - Collect sample data content analysis Weeks 12-14: Analysis & Interpretation - Clean wrangle data tidy format - Create descriptive visualizations - Run inferential tests answer research questions Week 15: Publication - Assemble one-click Quarto report - Publish portfolio GitHub Pages - Present findings class

title: coursepackR - Instructor Customization Guide
text: Configure Package Metadata (5 min) Organize Courses (15 min) Create Weekly Materials (Ongoing) Customize R Functions (Optional, 20 min) Test Publish (15 min)

title: coursepackR - Instructor Customization Guide
text: Edit file: DESCRIPTION Key fields: - Package: Technical name (lowercase, spaces, hyphens). students type remotes::install_github() - Title: Human-readable name package/course(s) - Version: Start 01.00.00, increment minor version (02.00.00) major changes - Description: 2-3 sentences package provides
code: Package: mystatcourse          # Change from 'coursepackR' - use lowercase, no spaces Type: Package Title: Introduction to Statistics with R   # Your course title(s) Version: 01.00.00              # Start with version 01.00.00 Authors@R: person(   "Your Name",    email = "you@university.edu",    role = c("aut", "cre") ) Description: A course package providing weekly scaffolds and R/RStudio setup     for [YOUR COURSE DESCRIPTION]. Students access materials and manage     their projects through this package. License: MIT + file LICENSE Encoding: UTF-8 Roxygen: list(markdown = TRUE) RoxygenNote: 7.3.2

title: coursepackR - Instructor Customization Guide
text: Create one folder per course inst/courses/: Important naming conventions: - Course directories: lowercase (e.g., mystat101, stat_201) - Week directories: week_01, week_02, â€¦ week_15 (zero-padded) - Files can anything: .qmd files, R scripts, CSV data, PDFs, etc.

what: What Goes in Each Week Folder?
title: coursepackR - Instructor Customization Guide

what: The Neuroscience of Narrative: Why Humans Tell Stories
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Neuroscientist Lisa Feldman Barrettâ€™s theory constructed emotion suggests brain fundamentally prediction machine. constantly generates models world, tests models incoming sensory data, updates beliefs predictions fail. prediction-error cycle identical scientific method. Storr, Science Storytelling, argues narratives emerged cognitive tools managing social complexity. Stories model cause--effect relationships, simulate outcomes, allow groups coordinate behavior around shared beliefs. predictions world failâ€”story breaksâ€”experience cognitive dissonance. Resolution requires either changing story (updating hypothesis) rejecting evidence (confirmation bias). Control-Seeking Brain: Humans crave control predictability. Uncertainty triggers anxiety. Stories reduce uncertainty organizing chaotic experience patterns: beginning, middle, end. Scientific research performs function scale. personal anecdotes offer localized control (â€œunderstand experienceâ€), empirical research offers generalized control (â€œunderstand phenomenon affects many peopleâ€).

what: Case Study: â€œTwitch in the Time of Quarantineâ€
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Letâ€™s trace narrative structure applies real SIM Lab project. Inciting Incident: COVID-19 pandemic, specifically following March 2020 lockdowns, Twitch viewership spiked 87%. Anecdotal evidence suggested people turning livestreams cope isolation, unclear usage actually fulfilling psychological needs simply passing time. Protagonistâ€™s Quest: research team set determine increased engagement Twitch pandemic successfully meeting specific user needs. Theory Training: team turned Uses Gratifications Theory, specifically focusing two fundamental motivations: social integrative needs (need socialize friends family) tension release needs (need escape relieve anxiety). Twitch meeting needs, data show changes users interacted platformâ€™s synchronous chat functions. Antagonist: challenge methodological: measure human emotion social connection across millions lines text? data non-parametricâ€”meaning didnâ€™t follow normal distributionâ€”heavily skewed outliers, making standard mean-based statistical tests unreliable. Climax: Instead surveys, team collected analyzed chat logs 50 randomly selected Twitch channels, comparing data â€œpre-pandemicâ€ (January 2020) â€œearly pandemicâ€ (April 2020). used R SQL count unique chatters total messages, applied NRC Emotion Association Lexicon analyze sentiment text. Resolution: study revealed nuanced reality. Contrary expectations, number unique people chatting significantly increase. However, volume messages skyrocketed, emotional content general chat messages became significantly intense, increases positive negative sentiments. Sacred Flaw Exposed: hypothesis users seek comfort targeted, interpersonal interaction (tagging others) largely unsupported. Instead, data showed users â€œscreaming voidâ€â€”releasing tension broadcasting emotions general chat rather directing specific individuals.

what: The Replication Crisis: When Science Broke Its Promise
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: 2015, Open Science Collaboration attempted replicate 100 psychology studies published top-tier journals. 36% successfully replicated. wasnâ€™t fraudâ€”fragility. Small, undisclosed analytical decisions (â€œexclude outlier?â€ â€œcovariates include?â€) dramatically affected results. decisions buried researchersâ€™ heads lost proprietary software, replication became impossible. Mass communication research faces problem. Content analysis codebooks get lost. Data cleaning steps go undocumented. Statistical software like SPSS saves output sequence menu clicks produced . canâ€™t reproduce analysis six months later, can anyone else?

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Consider typical undergraduate workflow: Code media content Excel spreadsheet. Import SPSS. Click menus generate frequency tables. Copy-paste output Word document. Manually format tables. Submit Word doc â€œfinalâ€ product. â€™s wrong ? record decisions: recode variables? Exclude cases? Transform data? choices exist memory. Manual errors: Copy-paste mistakes invisible consequential. Non-reproducibility: data changes (new coders add rows, find errors), must repeat every manual step. Collaboration friction: Collaborators canâ€™t see verify process.

what: Code as Recipe: The Literate Programming Solution
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: 1984, computer scientist Donald Knuth proposed literate programming: code explanatory text woven together document. reader sees just results logic produced . Modern tools like Quarto (predecessor R Markdown) realize Knuthâ€™s vision research. Quarto document (.qmd) contains: Narrative text: explanations, interpretations, context (written Markdown). Executable code: R chunks load data, clean , analyze , generate visualizations. Output: Tables, figures, statistical results generated automatically document rendered. recipe metaphor: Think .qmd file recipe. Ingredients: Raw data files. Instructions: R code (â€œload file,â€ â€œfilter rows X > 5,â€ â€œrun Chi-Square testâ€). Final dish: rendered report (HTML, PDF, Word). ingredients change (new data arrives), donâ€™t rewrite recipeâ€”just re-run . output updates automatically.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: common mistake using paragraph text complex ideas. Use structure instead: Less effective: effective: second version uses headings lists guide reader structure. example demonstrates: - Loading packages - Reading external data - Data summarization - Visualization - Statistical testing - code narrative work together - complete research workflow one document
code: This study examines whether streamers with webcams get more donations.  We collected data from 50 streams. We measured average donations.  We compared streamers with and without webcams. We used a t-test to determine significance. ## Research Question  Do streamers with webcams receive higher average donations?  ## Data Collection  - **Sample**: 50 Twitch streams - **Metrics**: Average donation per stream, streamer webcam use - **Time period**: January-March 2024  ## Analysis  - Compared donation amounts between groups - Calculated means and standard deviations - Used independent samples t-test --- title: "Webcam Use and Viewer Engagement" author: "Your Name" date: today format: html ---  ## Research Question  Do streamers who use webcams attract more viewers than streamers without webcams?  ## Data Collection  I observed 20 Twitch streams and recorded: - Streamer name - Game played   - Webcam use (yes/no) - Average concurrent viewers  ```{r} #| label: load-packages #| message: false #| eval: false  library(tidyverse) library(ggplot2) ```  ```{r} #| label: load-data #| eval: false  # Load data streamers <- read.csv("data/streamer_observations.csv")  # Preview head(streamers) ```  ## Analysis  ### Descriptive Statistics  ```{r} #| label: descriptives #| eval: false  # Calculate means by webcam use streamers %>%   group_by(webcam) %>%   summarize(     n = n(),     mean_viewers = mean(avg_viewers),     sd_viewers = sd(avg_viewers)   ) ```  ### Visualization  ```{r} #| label: visualization #| fig-width: 7 #| fig-height: 5 #| eval: false  ggplot(streamers, aes(x = webcam, y = avg_viewers, fill = webcam)) +   geom_boxplot() +   labs(     title = "Average Viewers by Webcam Use",     x = "Uses Webcam",     y = "Average Concurrent Viewers"   ) +   theme_minimal() +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("No" = "gray", "Yes" = "steelblue")) ```  ### Statistical Test  ```{r} #| label: ttest #| eval: false  # Independent samples t-test t_result <- t.test(avg_viewers ~ webcam, data = streamers) t_result ```  ## Results  In this example, streamers who used webcams had higher average viewers than those without. The statistical test would determine if this difference is significant.  ## Conclusion  This demonstrates how Quarto integrates code, analysis, and narrative into one reproducible document. You'll apply these skills throughout the course.

code: # Codebook Planning: Twitch Chat Toxicity  ## Research Question Is toxic chat more prevalent in competitive games (ranked matches) than casual games?  ## Variables to Measure  ### Independent Variable: Game Type - **Definition**: Whether the stream shows ranked (competitive) or unranked (casual) gameplay - **Possible Values**: Ranked, Unranked, Mixed - **Decision Rules**:    - If title says "ranked" = Ranked   - If streamer is in ranked queue = Ranked   - Otherwise = Unranked  ### Dependent Variable: Message Toxicity - **Definition**: Whether a chat message contains insulting, hateful, or derogatory language - **Possible Values**: Toxic, Neutral - **Examples**:   - Toxic: "You're trash," "Get better," "Kill yourself"   - Neutral: "nice play," "good job," "what rank are you?" - **Decision Rules**:    - If message contains insult = Toxic   - If message is sarcastic insult = Toxic (because context matters)   - Otherwise = Neutral

what: Tenacity: â€œItâ€™s Always Been This Wayâ€
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Tenacity belief sustained repetition tradition. claim repeated often enough, feels true. epistemology folklore, cultural norms, inherited wisdom. Example: â€œViolent video games cause real-world aggressionâ€ became conventional wisdom 1990s despite weak evidence. Parents, politicians, pundits repeated claim often acquired status common sense. Strength: Tenacity provides social cohesion. Shared beliefs bind communities.Weakness: Tenacity resists new evidence. privileges tradition truth.

previous_headings: Overview > Epistemology: The Problem of Knowledge
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Authority-based knowledge relies testimony credible sources: professors, journalists, scientists, religious leaders. efficientâ€”canâ€™t personally verify every claim, defer expertise. Example: people believe Earth orbits Sun â€™ve done math, astronomers say . Strength: Authority allows knowledge scale. Civilization depends trust specialized expertise.Weakness: Authority can abused. Experts can wrong, biased, corrupt. Appeals authority shut critical thinking.

previous_headings: Overview > Epistemology: The Problem of Knowledge
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Intuition gut-level knowing. â€™s fast, automatic, often accurate familiar domains (experienced doctors diagnosing symptoms, chess masters recognizing patterns). intuition also vulnerable cognitive biases. Example: â€œillusory truth effectâ€ demonstrates repeated exposure claim makes feel true, even â€™s false. propaganda works. Strength: Intuition fast often adaptive.Weakness: Intuition error-prone novel complex domains. mistakes familiarity truth.

previous_headings: Overview > Epistemology: The Problem of Knowledge
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Empiricism grounds knowledge observation measurement. scientific method formalized empiricism: make observations, form hypotheses, collect data, test predictions, revise theories. Example: Claims video game effects tested experiments, surveys, longitudinal studies. donâ€™t rely intuition anecdotesâ€”measure outcomes calculate probabilities. Strength: Empiricism self-correcting. new evidence contradicts old theories, theories change.Weakness: Empiricism slow resource-intensive. canâ€™t answer ethical questions (â€œban violent games?â€) empirical ones (â€œincrease aggression?â€). scientific attitude: Science doesnâ€™t reject authority, intuition, tradition. subjects empirical scrutiny. claim isnâ€™t true â€™s old, popular, endorsed expertsâ€”â€™s true survives attempts disprove .

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Philosopher Karl Popper argued science defined verification falsifiability: possibility proven wrong. claim scientific can specify conditions false.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Example 1: â€œStreamers webcams receive donations streamers without webcams.â€ falsifiable. collect data 100 streamers, compare donation rates, find difference (opposite pattern). claim risk proven false. Example 2: â€œExposure negative news increases anxiety.â€ Falsifiable. randomly assign participants read negative vs.Â neutral news, measure anxiety, find difference.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Example 1: â€œGood streamers inherently likable.â€ falsifiable. â€œGoodâ€ â€œlikableâ€ circularâ€”streamer isnâ€™t likable, can redefine â€œgood.â€ â€™s observation disprove . Example 2: â€œEverything happens reason.â€ falsifiable. matter happens, claim holds. Unfalsifiable claims may meaningful (philosophically, spiritually) â€™re scientific. falsifiability matters: Science advances eliminating bad ideas. theory immune disconfirmation, canâ€™t guide research. Falsifiable hypotheses force researchers take intellectual risksâ€”risk-taking produces reliable knowledge.

previous_headings: Overview > Induction vs.Â Deduction: Two Modes of Reasoning
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Induction moves specific observations general principles. gather data, notice patterns, infer theory. Example: coding 500 tweets esports fans, notice tweets mentioning rival games (â€œValorant trashâ€) predict higher engagement (retweets, replies). induce theory: â€œ-group/-group dynamics drive social media engagement gaming communities.â€ Strength: Induction exploratory generative. discovers new patterns.Weakness: Induction vulnerable overgeneralization. text: Developed Horton Wohl (1956), PSI describes one-sided emotional relationships audiences media figures. Viewers treat TV hosts, streamers, influencers friends despite reciprocal relationship. Core concepts: Illusion intimacy: Streamers address viewers directly, creating sense personal connection. Pseudo-reciprocity: Viewers respond relationship mutual (gifting subscriptions, defending streamers criticism). Empirical prediction: Viewers watch streamer >10 hours/week report higher PSI scores (measured via validated scales) casual viewers. SIM Lab application: PSI streamers predict donation behavior? vary platform (Twitch vs.Â YouTube Gaming)?

what: Case Study: Applying Theory to a Research Question
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Research Question: Twitch streamers receive donations others? Theory Selection: Parasocial Interaction (PSI) Theoretical reasoning: PSI predicts viewers donate streamers feel emotionally connected . Donations form pseudo-reciprocityâ€”viewers â€œgive backâ€ streamers make feel valued. Hypothesis: H1: Streamers use webcams (increasing perceived intimacy) receive higher average donations streamers without webcams. H2: Streamers respond chat messages frequently (increasing interaction) receive higher donations. H3: PSI intensity (measured via viewer surveys) mediate relationship interaction frequency donations. Operationalization: IV1: Webcam use (yes/) IV2: Chat response rate (% chat messages acknowledged) DV: Average donation per stream (dollars) Mediator: PSI intensity (7-point Likert scale) Data collection: Observe 50 Twitch streams. Code webcam use chat interactions. Survey 200 viewers across streams. Measure PSI using PSI-Process Scale (Schramm & Hartmann, 2008). Correlate PSI scores self-reported donation behavior.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: chapter framed theory lens focuses attention generates predictions: Grand theories (Marxism, Psychoanalysis) explain broad human behavior hard test Middle-range theories (PSI, Social Identity, Agenda Setting, Framing, Uses & Gratifications) specific enough test broad enough generalize Parasocial Interaction explains one-sided emotional relationships audiences media figures Social Identity Theory predicts group membership shapes identity, leading -group favoritism -group derogation Agenda Setting examines media coverage shapes public priorities Framing Theory studies presenting information differently influences interpretation Uses & Gratifications asks audiences media satisfy needs Variables building blocks hypotheses: IVs (causes), DVs (effects), mediators (explain relationships), moderators (change relationships) Good theories generate testable, falsifiable hypotheses

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Agenda Setting: Media influence audiences think (topic salience) Concept: abstract idea within theory (e.g., "intimacy," "identity") Dependent Variable (DV): outcome effect measured Framing Theory: information presentation influences interpretation Grand Theory: Broad explanatory framework (hard test empirically) Hypothesis: testable prediction derived theory Independent Variable (IV): cause predictor manipulated measured Mediator: variable explains IV affects DV Middle-Range Theory: Theory specific enough test broad enough generalize Moderator: variable changes strength direction IV-DV relationship Parasocial Interaction (PSI): One-sided emotional relationship audience media figure Social Identity Theory: Group membership shapes self-concept intergroup behavior Uses & Gratifications: Audiences actively select media satisfy specific needs Variable: measurable characteristic varies across observations

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Title: Webcam Use Viewer Donations Twitch: Parasocial Interaction Perspective Research Question: Twitch streamers use webcams receive higher average donations per stream streamers without webcams? Background & Significance: Live-streaming platforms like Twitch created new economic models audience donations sustain creators. Understanding drives donations can inform streamer strategies platform design. Existing research parasocial interaction (PSI) suggests visual intimacy strengthens perceived relationships audiences media figures (Horton & Wohl, 1956; Dibble et al., 2016), studies examine PSI live-streaming contexts. Theoretical Framework: Parasocial Interaction Theory predicts audiences form one-sided emotional bonds media figures. Webcam use increases perceived intimacy allowing viewers see streamersâ€™ facial expressions reactions, thus strengthening PSI intensity. Higher PSI predict greater pseudo-reciprocity behaviors, including donations. Hypotheses: H1: Streamers use webcams receive higher average donations per stream streamers without webcams. H2: Viewer-reported PSI intensity mediate relationship webcam use donation behavior. Method: observe 50 Twitch streams (25 webcams, 25 without) across three game genres (FPS, RPG, strategy). stream, record: (1) webcam presence (yes/), (2) total donations received 2-hour session, (3) viewer count, (4) chat activity (messages per minute). also survey 200 viewers across streams using PSI-Process Scale (Schramm & Hartmann, 2008) measure PSI intensity. Data analyzed using independent samples t-tests (H1) mediation analysis (H2). Feasibility: Twitch streams publicly accessible, requiring IRB approval observational data. PSI survey require IRB exemption (anonymous, minimal risk). Data collection (50 streams Ã— 2 hours = 100 hours observation) can distributed across 4 weeks. Surveys can administered via Qualtrics linked Twitch chats moderator permission. prospectus clear, focused, feasible. passes â€œexplain project 60 secondsâ€ test.

what: Case Study: Observing Twitch Raid Culture
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Goal: Understand Twitch â€œraidsâ€ (one streamer sends viewers another channel) function community-building rituals. Structured Listening Process: Raiding streamer announces: â€œâ€™re raiding [name]! Letâ€™s show love!â€ Chat floods new channel emotes greetings. Receiving streamer thanks raiders shouts raiding streamer. raids reciprocal (streamers raid regularly). raids target small streamers (charity raids). raids hostile (raid negative spamâ€”rare exists). RQ1: â€œproportion raids reciprocal vs.Â one-directional?â€ RQ2: â€œcharity raids (large streamer small streamer) increase small streamerâ€™s follower count 24 hours post-raid?â€ RQ3: â€œstreamers linguistically frame raids (gift, obligation, business transaction)?â€ Raid type: Reciprocal, Charity, Random, Hostile Receiving streamer response: Thanks + shoutout, Thanks , acknowledgment Chat sentiment: Positive, Neutral, Negative systematic process ensures research questions coding categories reflect communityâ€™s reality, assumptions.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Reliability: Can measure applied consistently? two coders use operational definition, get results? Validity: measure actually capture concept claim measure? tension: Simple measures (e.g., counting swear words) highly reliable low validity (profanity â‰  toxicity). Complex measures (e.g., coding intent context) valid harder apply reliably. Solution: Pilot test operational definitions. inter-coder reliability low (<.70), definition vague. Refine .

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Variables labels names. ranking implied. Examples: Game genre (FPS, RPG, Strategy, Sports) Streamer gender (Male, Female, Non-binary, Prefer say) Platform (Twitch, YouTube Gaming, Facebook Gaming) Allowed operations: Count frequencies, calculate mode (common category), test association (Chi-Square). allowed: Calculate means say one category â€œhigherâ€ another.

what: Ordinal: Categories With Order (But Unequal Intervals)
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Variables rank order, distance ranks undefined. Examples: Likert scales: â€œmuch agree?â€ (1 = Strongly Disagree, 2 = Disagree, 3 = Neutral, 4 = Agree, 5 = Strongly Agree) Rank-ordered preferences: â€œRank top 3 gamesâ€ Education level: (High School < Bachelorâ€™s < Masterâ€™s < PhD) Allowed operations: Calculate median, test correlation (Spearmanâ€™s rho). Caution means: Technically, shouldnâ€™t calculate mean ordinal data (â€œdistanceâ€ Disagree Neutral isnâ€™t necessarily Neutral Agree), practice, researchers often treat Likert scales interval data.

what: Interval: Equal Intervals, No True Zero
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: distance values consistent, zero arbitrary (doesnâ€™t mean â€œabsenceâ€). Examples: Temperature Fahrenheit (0Â°F doesnâ€™t mean â€œtemperatureâ€) IQ scores (100 average, 0 doesnâ€™t mean â€œintelligenceâ€) Allowed operations: Calculate mean, standard deviation, run t-tests ANOVAs. allowed: Say â€œ100Â°F twice hot 50Â°Fâ€ (zero arbitrary). Rare communication research: variables nominal, ordinal, ratio.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: gold standard. Zero means â€œnoneâ€ â€œabsence.â€ Examples: Number toxic messages (0 = toxic messages) Stream duration (0 = stream) Donations dollars (0 = donations) Follower count (0 = followers) Allowed operations: Everythingâ€”mean, median, ratios (â€œStreamer twice many followers Streamer Bâ€). matters: know variableâ€™s level measurement, know statistical tests appropriate.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: concepts resist simple operationalization. measure â€œauthenticity,â€ â€œcommunity,â€ â€œidentityâ€? Strategy 1: Break measurable components Concept: Streamer authenticity Components: Self-disclosure (number personal stories shared per stream) Emotional expressiveness (coded facial expressions: genuine smiles, eye contact) Consistency (alignment stream persona social media persona) canâ€™t measure â€œauthenticityâ€ directly, can measure behaviors associated perceived authenticity. Strategy 2: Use validated scales someone already developed reliable scale, use . Donâ€™t reinvent wheel. Examples: Parasocial Interaction: PSI-Process Scale (Schramm & Hartmann, 2008) Social Identity: Social Identity Scale (Cameron, 2004) Media Credibility: Source Credibility Scale (Ohanian, 1990) Strategy 3: Multi-method triangulation Use multiple measures capture different facets. Concept: Community cohesion Measures: Survey: â€œfeel like belong communityâ€ (Likert scale) Behavioral: Frequency repeat participation (returning streams/threads) Content analysis: Use â€œâ€ language vs.Â â€œâ€ language chat

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Research Question: â€œauthenticâ€ streamers successful â€œperformativeâ€ streamers? Problem: â€œAuthenticityâ€ vibe, variable. Step 1: Conceptual definition Authenticity = perception streamer genuine, unscripted, self-consistent (playing character). Step 2: observable behaviors signal authenticity? Sharing personal stories unrelated gameplay Emotional expressiveness (laughing, frustration, excitement) Responding spontaneously chat (reading script) Consistency across platforms (Twitter persona matches stream persona) Step 3: Operational definitions Self-disclosure: Count personal stories (defined anecdotes streamerâ€™s non-gaming life) per stream hour. Emotional expressiveness: Coded presence/absence facial webcam + number audible emotional reactions (laughter, sighs, exclamations) per stream hour. Chat responsiveness: Percentage chat questions acknowledged within 2 minutes. Cross-platform consistency: Analyze 20 tweets 20 stream clips. Code tone â€œcasual,â€ â€œprofessional,â€ â€œperformative.â€ Consistency = proportion matching codes. Step 4: Combine Authenticity Index Standardize measure (z-scores), average , create Authenticity Index (range: -3 +3, higher = authentic). Step 5: Test Correlate Authenticity Index â€œsuccessâ€ measures (average concurrent viewers, subscriber count, donation revenue).

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: chapter taught cognitive leap abstract concepts concrete measurements: Operationalization translates â€œvibesâ€ (intuitive impressions) â€œvariablesâ€ (measurable indicators) Every variable needs conceptual definition (means theoretically) operational definition (measure ) reliability-validity trade-: simple measures reliable may lack validity; complex measures capture nuance harder apply consistently Levels measurement (NOIR): Nominal (categories), Ordinal (ranked categories), Interval (equal intervals, true zero), Ratio (equal intervals + true zero) Different measurement levels permit different statistical operations Complex concepts require breaking components, using validated scales, multi-method triangulation Common mistakes: conflating concepts, unjustified proxies, oversimplification, unmeasurable definitions Operational definitions must specific, observable, replicable

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Conceptual definition: Abstract, theoretical meaning variable Interval level: Equal intervals values, true zero (rare communication research) Level measurement: mathematical properties variable (NOIR) Nominal level: Categories without order (e.g., gender, platform, genre) Operational definition: Concrete, step--step instructions measuring variable Operationalization: process translating concepts measurable variables Ordinal level: Ranked categories unequal intervals (e.g., Likert scales, education level) Proxy measure: indirect indicator used direct measurement impossible Ratio level: Equal intervals plus true zero (e.g., follower count, message frequency) Reliability: Consistency measurement across coders time Validity: Whether measure actually captures intended concept Variable: measurable characteristic varies across observations

text: unit fit ONE category per variable. Overlap creates ambiguity. Bad example: Variable: Streamer activity Categories: Playing game Talking chat Showing gameplay Problem: streamer can play game talking chat. categories overlap. code: # Codebook: Twitch Chat Toxicity Study  **Project**: Analysis of toxicity in competitive gaming streams   **Coder**: [Your Name]   **Date**: [Date]   **Version**: 1.3  ---  ## 1. Unit of Analysis Individual chat message  ## 2. Variables  ### Variable 1: Message Type - [Categories and definitions]  ### Variable 2: Toxicity - [Subcategories and examples]  ## 3. Decision Rules - Rule 1: [Description] - Rule 2: [Description]  ## 4. Examples  **Example 1**: "GG EZ"   - Message Type: Toxic   - Toxicity: Personal insult   - Target: In-game players   - Reasoning: "EZ" mocks opponents  **Example 2**: "This lag is unplayable"   - Message Type: Other   - Toxicity: N/A   - Reasoning: Criticism of technical issue, not a person  ---  ## Appendix A: Slur List [Do not reproduce slurs in assignmentsâ€”reference comprehensive lists maintained by organizations like the Anti-Defamation League]

text: Conceptual Definition: emotional valence (positive--negative spectrum) judgeâ€™s verbal feedback. Measurement Scale (code one category per unit): 3 = Strongly Positive: Compliments contestantâ€™s ability superlatives, predicts success, expresses genuine enthusiasm. Uses words like â€œincredible,â€ â€œstunning,â€ â€œperfect,â€ â€œone best,â€ direct encouragement (â€œwin â€). 2 = Mildly Positive: Acknowledges strengths, appreciates effort, identifies areas excellence without superlatives. Uses phrases like â€œnice job,â€ â€œliked interpretation,â€ â€œstrong vocals,â€ â€œgood control.â€ 1 = Neutral/Constructive: Provides constructive feedback, suggestions, technical analysis without judgment. Uses phrases like â€œtry different approach,â€ â€œslower tempo,â€ â€œwork breath control,â€ â€œinteresting choice.â€ Can include positive negative elements balanced proportion. 0 = Negative: Expresses criticism, disappointment, doubt, concern. Uses phrases like â€œwasnâ€™t best,â€ â€œ-key,â€ â€œseemed nervous,â€ â€œdidnâ€™t connect,â€ implies contestant may eliminated. Decision Rules: comment contains strong positive strong negative elements, code dominant emotion. (Example: â€œmostly great, lost bridgeâ€ = code 2 (Mildly Positive), praise dominates.) tone ambiguous, look qualifiers. â€œGood. .â€ often indicates Neutral (1), whereas â€œgood really shows growthâ€ indicates Mildly Positive (2). Sarcasm counts Negative (0). Example: â€œOh wow, definitely high notesâ€ = Negative. Judgeâ€™s facial expression (grimace, smile) can supplement coding words ambiguous. Primary coding based words alone. Personal comments (â€œseem like great personâ€) donâ€™t directly evaluate singing = Neutral (1).

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: chapter taught construct codebooks produce reliable, replicable content analysis: Content analysis must systematic (rules apply uniformly), objective (coders follow rules, intuitions), quantitative (results expressed numbers) codebook â€œalgorithmâ€ human coders executeâ€”must explicit enough independent coders produce nearly identical results Complete codebooks include: unit analysis, variables, categories, decision rules, examples Categories must exhaustive (every unit fits somewhere) mutually exclusive (unit fits one category per variable) Decision rules handle edge cases ambiguity systematically Pilot testing identifies vague definitions common disagreements Inter-coder reliability (ICR) measures consistency: Cohenâ€™s Kappa (2 coders), Krippendorffâ€™s Alpha (number coders, measurement level) Acceptable reliability: Î± Îº â‰¥ .70 (adequate), â‰¥ .80 (excellent) Low reliability signals unclear definitions, insufficient training, inherently ambiguous constructs

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Cohenâ€™s Kappa (Îº): Inter-coder reliability metric 2 coders, corrects chance agreement Codebook: Systematic instructions coding content, including variable definitions, categories, decision rules Content analysis: Systematic, objective, quantitative analysis communication content Decision rule: Explicit guideline handling ambiguous edge cases Exhaustive categories: Category set every observation can classified (uncodeable cases) Inter-coder reliability (ICR): Consistency independent coders Krippendorffâ€™s Alpha (Î±): ICR metric number coders measurement level Mutually exclusive categories: Categories overlap (unit fits one) Operational definition: Concrete instructions identifying measuring variable Percent agreement: Simple reliability metric (agreements/total) doesnâ€™t correct chance Pilot testing: Preliminary coding phase test refine codebook Unit analysis: object coded (tweet, article, video, message)

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Formula: Agreement=Number agreementsTotal units coded \text{Agreement} = \frac{\text{Number agreements}}{\text{Total units coded}} Example: Two coders code 50 tweets. agree 40. Agreement=4050=0.80 (80%) \text{Agreement} = \frac{40}{50} = 0.80 \text{ (80\%)} Problem: Percent agreement doesnâ€™t account chance agreement. two categories (Toxic vs.Â Neutral), coders might agree 50% time just guessing.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Cohenâ€™s Kappa corrects chance agreement. Formula (simplified): Îº=Poâˆ’Pe1âˆ’Pe \kappa = \frac{P_o - P_e}{1 - P_e} : PoP_o = observed agreement PeP_e = expected agreement chance Interpretation: Îº = 1.0: Perfect agreement Îº = 0.8-1.0: Excellent Îº = 0.7-0.79: Acceptable Îº < 0.7: Unreliable (revise codebook) Limitation: Cohenâ€™s Kappa works 2 coders .

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Krippendorffâ€™s Alpha gold standard: Works number coders (2, 3, 10, etc.) Works level measurement (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio) Accounts chance agreement sample size Formula (conceptual): Î±=1âˆ’Observed disagreementExpected disagreement chance \alpha = 1 - \frac{\text{Observed disagreement}}{\text{Expected disagreement chance}} Interpretation: Cohenâ€™s Kappa (â‰¥.80 excellent, .70-.79 acceptable, <.70 unreliable). calculate: Use R, Python, online calculators (donâ€™t hand).

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Î± Îº < .70: Identify problem variables: Calculate reliability variable separately. lowest agreement? Examine edge cases: Review disagreements. coders confused specific examples? Clarify definitions: Add decision rules rephrase operational definitions. Retrain coders: Meet coders discuss codebook. Ensure shared understanding. Re-pilot: Code new subsample recalculate reliability. Example: Problem: Coders disagree whether â€œGG EZâ€ toxic (Îº = .65). Diagnosis: One coder codes â€œGGâ€ variants neutral (sportsmanship). codes â€œGG EZâ€ toxic (mockery). Solution: Add decision rule: â€œâ€˜GG EZâ€™ coded toxic â€˜EZâ€™ mocks opponent. â€˜GGâ€™ alone neutral.â€ Re-pilot: Îº improves .78.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Many student projects one coder (). Without second coder, canâ€™t calculate ICR. Solutions: Partner classmate: Exchange datasets code â€™s samples. Code twice, separately: Code pilot, wait 1 week, code without looking original results. Compare two rounds (intra-coder reliability). Acknowledge limitation: â€œstudy conducted single coder. codebook designed replicability, inter-coder reliability assessed. Future research verify findings multiple coders.â€

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Every sample limitations. responsibility acknowledge , eliminate (often impossible). Example biases: Temporal bias: Analyzing February 2024 tweets may represent December 2024 (holiday effects, new game releases). Platform bias: Twitch users â‰  YouTube Gaming users â‰  Facebook Gaming users. Findings one platform may transfer. Survivorship bias: Analyzing popular streamers ignores quit due harassment burnout. address: limitations section, write: â€œstudy sampled top 100 Twitch streamers viewership. findings may generalize small mid-tier streamers, face different economic pressures community dynamics. Future research examine stratified samples across viewership tiers.â€

Step 2: Select pilot sample: Randomly select 5 streams (10% final sample). stream provides ~100 chat messages = 500 total pilot messages. Step 3: Two coders independently code pilot. Step 4: Calculate Krippendorffâ€™s Alpha: Variable: Message type (Gameplay comment, Social interaction, Toxic, ) Î± = .68 (acceptable threshold) Step 5: Diagnose: Coders disagree â€œToxicâ€ vs.Â â€œGameplay comment.â€ Example: â€œplay trashâ€ â€” Coder : Toxic (insult). Coder B: Gameplay comment (criticism). Step 6: Revise codebook: Add decision rule: â€œCriticism gameplay (â€˜strategy didnâ€™t workâ€™) toxic. Criticism player (â€˜trashâ€™) toxic. message includes â€˜â€™ (referring action) rather â€˜â€™ (referring person), code Gameplay comment.â€ Step 7: Re-pilot: Code 5 new streams. Î± = .76 (acceptable). Step 8: Code full sample confidence.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: chapter taught define study boundaries verify codebookâ€™s reliability: Census (entire population) rarely feasible; samples must represent population acknowledge limitations Sampling frame specific list draw sample (often narrower ideal population) Sampling techniques: Simple random (unbiased), systematic (every kth item), stratified (ensuring subgroup representation), purposive (theory-driven), convenience (easy biased) Sample size depends research goals: 20-50 exploratory, 100-300 descriptive, larger inferential statistics Pilot testing (typically 10% sample) identifies codebook ambiguities estimates reliability Inter-coder reliability measures consistency: percent agreement (simple flawed), Cohenâ€™s Kappa (2 coders), Krippendorffâ€™s Alpha (number coders, gold standard) Acceptable reliability: Î± Îº â‰¥ .70 (adequate), â‰¥ .80 (excellent) Low reliability troubleshooting: identify problem variables, examine edge cases, clarify definitions, retrain coders, re-pilot Sampling bias (temporal, platform, survivorship) limits generalizabilityâ€”acknowledge explicitly limitations section

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Census: Analysis every member population (rarely feasible) Convenience sampling: Selecting easily accessible cases (quick biased) Generalizability: extent sample findings apply broader population Inter-coder reliability (ICR): Consistency independent coders Krippendorffâ€™s Alpha (Î±): Reliability metric number coders measurement levels Pilot study: Preliminary coding phase test codebook estimate reliability Population: complete set cases interest Purposive sampling: Theory-driven selection specific cases (statistically representative) Sample: subset population selected analysis Sampling bias: Systematic - -representation certain population characteristics Sampling frame: specific list sample drawn Simple random sampling: Every unit equal probability selection (unbiased) Stratified sampling: Random sampling within defined subgroups ensure representation Systematic sampling: Selecting every kth item (e.g., every 10th article)

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Advantages: Preserves column names (spaces allowed). Better type detection (automatically parses dates numbers). Faster large files. Pro tip: Always inspect data import:
code: library(readr)  raw_data <- read_csv("data_raw/coding_sheet.csv") glimpse(raw_data)  # Shows column names and types head(raw_data)     # Shows first 6 rows

previous_headings: Overview > Common Data Problems and Solutions
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Problem: cells blank contain â€œNAâ€, â€œN/â€, â€œUnknownâ€. Solution: Standardize missing values: Decision: : Exclude rows missing data (listwise deletion)? Impute values (fill mode, median, logical guess)? Keep NA analyze complete cases (pairwise deletion)? Document choice justify methods section.
code: library(dplyr)  clean_data <- raw_data %>%   mutate(game = na_if(game, "Unknown")) %>%  # Convert "Unknown" to NA   mutate(game = na_if(game, ""))              # Convert empty strings to NA

previous_headings: Overview > Common Data Problems and Solutions
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Problem: Coders entered category different ways: â€œValorantâ€, â€œvalorantâ€, â€œVALORANTâ€, â€œValâ€ Solution: Standardize case_when() recode():
code: clean_data <- raw_data %>%   mutate(game = tolower(game)) %>%  # Convert to lowercase   mutate(game = case_when(     game %in% c("valorant", "val") ~ "Valorant",     game %in% c("overwatch", "ow") ~ "Overwatch",     game == "cs:go" ~ "CS:GO",     TRUE ~ game  # Keep everything else as is   ))

previous_headings: Overview > Common Data Problems and Solutions

text: Problem: observations coded twice accidentally. Solution: Remove duplicates: Caution: duplicates legitimate (e.g., two coders coded data reliability), donâ€™t delete â€”merge calculating ICR.
code: clean_data <- raw_data %>%   distinct()  # Keeps only unique rows

previous_headings: Overview > Common Data Problems and Solutions

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: diving complex tidyverse code, letâ€™s compare base R (â€™ve already learned) tidyverse (makes analysis easier). Understanding helps appreciate use tidyverse.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Filtering data (keep certain rows): Creating new columns: Selecting specific columns: use tidyverse? operations get complex, tidyverse code remains readable. Compare: pipe operator (%>%) lets read code left--right instead inside-.
code: # BASE R approach (what you know from Chapter 2) valorant_base <- clean_data[clean_data$game == "Valorant", ]  # TIDYVERSE approach (clearer to read) valorant_tidy <- clean_data %>%   filter(game == "Valorant") # BASE R clean_data$is_toxic <- ifelse(clean_data$toxicity == "Toxic", 1, 0)  # TIDYVERSE clean_data <- clean_data %>%   mutate(is_toxic = if_else(toxicity == "Toxic", 1, 0)) # BASE R minimal_base <- clean_data[, c("id", "game", "toxicity")]  # TIDYVERSE minimal_tidy <- clean_data %>%   select(id, game, toxicity) # BASE R: calculate average viewers for webcam streamers (hard to read) mean(clean_data[clean_data$uses_webcam == TRUE, ]$viewers)  # TIDYVERSE: same operation (reads like English) clean_data %>%   filter(uses_webcam == TRUE) %>%   summarize(avg_viewers = mean(viewers))

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Common mistake: Forgetting use group_by() summarize(). Without grouping, get one summary entire dataset instead one per group.
code: # Calculate toxicity rate by game summary_stats <- clean_data %>%   group_by(game) %>%   summarize(     total_messages = n(),     toxic_messages = sum(is_toxic),     toxicity_rate = toxic_messages / total_messages   )

previous_headings: Overview > Essential dplyr Verbs > The Five Core dplyr Verbs
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
code: # Sort games by toxicity rate (descending) summary_stats %>%   arrange(desc(toxicity_rate))  # Sort ascending (lowest to highest) summary_stats %>%   arrange(toxicity_rate)

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: real power comes combining verbs: Read aloud: â€œTake clean_data, filter FPS games, create toxicity indicator, group game webcam use, calculate summaries, sort rate.â€ tidyverse exists: code reads like instructions.
code: # Start with raw data, end with a sorted summary table result <- clean_data %>%   filter(game %in% c("Valorant", "Overwatch")) %>%  # Only FPS games   mutate(is_toxic = if_else(toxicity == "Toxic", 1, 0)) %>%  # Create binary   group_by(game, uses_webcam) %>%  # Group by game AND webcam   summarize(     total = n(),     toxic = sum(is_toxic),     rate = toxic / total   ) %>%   arrange(desc(rate))  # Sort by toxicity rate

code: # Data Cleaning Log # Author: [Your Name] # Date: 2024-10-15  # 1. Imported raw data raw_data <- read_csv("data_raw/twitch_chat_coding.csv")  # 2. Standardized game names clean_data <- raw_data %>%   mutate(game = tolower(game)) %>%   mutate(game = case_when(     game %in% c("valorant", "val") ~ "Valorant",     game %in% c("overwatch", "ow") ~ "Overwatch",     TRUE ~ game   ))  # 3. Converted toxicity to binary clean_data <- clean_data %>%   mutate(is_toxic = if_else(toxicity == "Toxic", 1, 0))  # 4. Removed rows with missing game data (n = 12 rows excluded) clean_data <- clean_data %>%   filter(!is.na(game))  # 5. Saved cleaned data write_csv(clean_data, "data_clean/twitch_chat_clean.csv")

what: Case Study: Cleaning a Twitch Chat Dataset
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Raw data: 500 chat messages coded game, message type, toxicity. Problem 1: Game names inconsistent (â€œValorantâ€ vs.Â â€œvalorantâ€ vs.Â â€œValâ€). Solution: Standardize tolower() case_when(). Problem 2: Toxicity column values: â€œToxicâ€, â€œNeutralâ€, â€œâ€, â€œ???â€ Solution: Recode â€œ???â€ NA (ambiguous). Collapse â€œâ€ â€œNeutralâ€ (non-toxic). Problem 3: Coder ID stored numeric (1, 2) categorical (â€œCoder â€, â€œCoder Bâ€). Solution: Convert factor labels. Final cleaned dataset: 488 rows (12 excluded missing game data) 4 variables: id, game, message_type, is_toxic Ready analysis tidyverse exists: code reads like instructions.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: chapter taught transform messy data analysis-ready datasets: Tidy data principle: row = one observation, column = one variable, cell = one value Importing data: Use readr::read_csv() better type detection column name handling Common data problems: missing values (NA, blanks), inconsistent categories (spelling variations), duplicates, incorrect data types dplyr verbs: filter() (keep rows), select() (keep columns), mutate() (create/modify columns), group_by() + summarize() (aggregate), arrange() (sort) Reshaping: pivot_wider() (long wide), pivot_longer() (wide long) Factors: Categorical data defined levels ordering; use forcats package manipulation Document every decision: Cleaning logs ensure reproducibility defend accusations p-hacking Missing data strategies: Listwise deletion, imputation, keeping NAs (depends context reasons missingness)

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Cleaning log: Documentation data transformations decisions dplyr: R package providing verbs data manipulation Factor: R data structure categorical variables defined levels Imputation: Filling missing values estimated values (mean, median, model-based) Listwise deletion: Removing observation missing data variable Long format: row represents one measurement (tidy analysis) Missing data: Absent values (NA R) requiring handling decisions Mutate: dplyr verb creating modifying variables Pairwise deletion: Using available data calculation (missing data variables doesnâ€™t exclude observation entirely) Piping: Chaining operations %>% operator Pivot: Reshaping data long wide formats Tidy data: Data structure row = observation, column = variable, cell = value Wide format: row represents one entity multiple measurement columns

text: chapter introduces descriptive statistics data visualization. 11 weeks setup, finally get see data says. first payoff momentâ€”reveal patterns â€™ve worked systematically uncover.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: ggplot2 built consistent logic called Grammar Graphics (Wilkinson, 2005). jumping complex charts, letâ€™s build one step--step understand piece.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Goal: Create bar chart showing count toxic vs.Â neutral messages. Step 1: Start data creates blank canvas. â€™ve told ggplot â€œuse dataset,â€ plot. Step 2: Add aesthetic mappings (aes) Now ggplot knows â€œput message_type x-axis,â€ still havenâ€™t said visualize (bars? points? lines?). Step 3: Add geometry layer Now chart! + adds layers (like Photoshop layers). geom_bar() says â€œdraw bars.â€ Step 4: Customize labels colors Final result: clean, labeled bar chart ready publication.
code: library(ggplot2)  # Just the data layer (nothing plots yet) ggplot(data = clean_data) ggplot(data = clean_data, aes(x = message_type)) ggplot(data = clean_data, aes(x = message_type)) +   geom_bar() ggplot(clean_data, aes(x = message_type)) +   geom_bar(fill = "steelblue") +   labs(     title = "Distribution of Message Types in Twitch Chat",     x = "Message Type",     y = "Count"   )

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Every ggplot2 chart follows template: Components: data: cleaned dataset (Chapter 11) aes(): Aesthetic mappings (variables map x, y, color, size) **geom_*()**: Geometry (bar, line, point, histogram, boxplot) labs(): Labels titles + (plus sign): Adds layers (pipe %>%) Common beginner mistake: Using %>% instead + ggplot2. Remember: - %>% dplyr (data manipulation) - + ggplot2 (visualization)
code: ggplot(data = YOUR_DATA, aes(x = X_VARIABLE, y = Y_VARIABLE)) +   geom_CHART_TYPE() +   labs(title = "TITLE", x = "X LABEL", y = "Y LABEL")

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Think ggplot2 building sandwich: Bread (data): ggplot(clean_data) Filling (aesthetics): aes(x = game, y = viewers) Toppings (geometry): + geom_col() Garnish (labels): + labs(title = "...") + adds another layer. can stack many needed:
code: ggplot(clean_data, aes(x = game, y = viewers)) +   geom_col(fill = "coral") +   labs(title = "Average Viewers by Game", x = "Game", y = "Viewers") +   theme_minimal() +  # Clean background   coord_flip()  # Horizontal bars

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Connecting back Chapter 1, chart visual story: X-axis setting (context: groups categories?). Y-axis plot (changes varies?). bars/points characters (data). job: make story clear, cluttered. Bad visualization: 12 colors, overlapping labels, title.Good visualization: One focal point, clear labels, interpretable glance.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Use comparing frequencies proportions across categories. Example: many messages coded toxic vs.Â neutral? Interpretation: â€œToxicâ€ bar much shorter â€œNeutral,â€ toxicity relatively rare.
code: library(ggplot2)  ggplot(clean_data, aes(x = message_type)) +   geom_bar(fill = "steelblue") +   labs(     title = "Distribution of Message Types in Twitch Chat",     x = "Message Type",     y = "Count"   )

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Compare categories across groups. Example: Toxicity game (Valorant vs.Â Overwatch). Interpretation: Valorantâ€™s â€œToxicâ€ bar taller Overwatchâ€™s, Valorant chat toxic.
code: ggplot(clean_data, aes(x = game, fill = message_type)) +   geom_bar(position = "dodge") +  # Side-by-side bars   labs(     title = "Message Types by Game",     x = "Game",     y = "Count",     fill = "Message Type"   ) +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("Toxic" = "red", "Neutral" = "gray"))

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Show proportions within category. Interpretation: Valorantâ€™s red slice larger Overwatchâ€™s, higher proportion Valorant messages toxic (even total count similar).
code: ggplot(clean_data, aes(x = game, fill = message_type)) +   geom_bar(position = "fill") +  # Stacked as proportions   labs(     title = "Proportion of Toxic vs. Neutral Messages by Game",     x = "Game",     y = "Proportion",     fill = "Message Type"   )

what: Question 1: Judge Tone by Contestant Demographics
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Data prep (R): Expected output (example): Visualization 1: Judge Tone Gender Interpretation: - Male contestants receive slightly higher average tone (M = 2.35) vs.Â female (M = 2.18) - Difference small (~0.17 points 0-3 scale) - Error bars show substantial variability within gender group Visualization 2: Judge Tone Race/Ethnicity Interpretation: - Visual inspection shows tone scores vary ethnicity (ranging ~2.0-2.4) - Horizontally-oriented chart makes category labels easier read - Viridis color palette colorblind-friendly
code: library(tidyverse) library(ggplot2)  # Load cleaned data idol_data <- read_csv("data_clean/idol_judge_feedback.csv")  # Summarize: Average judge tone by contestant gender tone_by_gender <- idol_data %>%   group_by(gender) %>%   summarize(     mean_tone = mean(tone, na.rm = TRUE),     sd_tone = sd(tone, na.rm = TRUE),     n = n()   )  print(tone_by_gender) gender       mean_tone  sd_tone    n Female          2.18    0.73     54 Male            2.35    0.68     91 Non-Binary      2.12    0.82     12 ggplot(tone_by_gender, aes(x = gender, y = mean_tone, fill = gender)) +   geom_col() +   geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = mean_tone - sd_tone,                      ymax = mean_tone + sd_tone),                 width = 0.2) +   labs(     title = "Average Judge Feedback Tone by Contestant Gender",     x = "Contestant Gender",     y = "Average Tone Score (0 = Negative, 3 = Strongly Positive)",     fill = "Gender"   ) +   ylim(0, 3) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "none") tone_by_ethnicity <- idol_data %>%   group_by(ethnicity) %>%   summarize(     mean_tone = mean(tone, na.rm = TRUE),     n = n()   ) %>%   filter(!is.na(ethnicity))  # Remove missing data  ggplot(tone_by_ethnicity, aes(x = reorder(ethnicity, mean_tone),                                y = mean_tone,                                fill = mean_tone)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "plasma") +   labs(     title = "Average Judge Feedback Tone by Contestant Race/Ethnicity",     x = "Race/Ethnicity",     y = "Average Tone Score",     fill = "Avg Tone"   ) +   coord_flip() +  # Horizontal bars for readability   ylim(0, 3) +   theme_minimal()

what: Question 2: Does Positive Feedback Predict Advancement?
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Data prep: Expected output: Visualization 3: Advancement Judge Feedback Tone Interpretation: - Contestants receiving positive feedback: 82 advanced, 21 eliminated (79.6% advancement rate) - Contestants receiving non-positive feedback: 15 advanced, 38 eliminated (28.3% advancement rate) - Strong relationship: positive feedback â†’ higher advancement probability Visualization 4: Judge-Specific Patterns Interpretation: - Compare across judges: judges give systematically higher/lower scores? - Compare within judges: judgeâ€™s feedback differ contestant gender? - Useful exploring potential bias patterns
code: # Create contingency table advancement_table <- idol_data %>%   mutate(tone_category = if_else(tone >= 2, "Positive", "Non-Positive")) %>%   group_by(tone_category, advancement) %>%   summarize(count = n())  print(advancement_table) tone_category    advancement    count Non-Positive          No           38 Non-Positive          Yes          15 Positive              No           21 Positive              Yes          82 ggplot(advancement_table, aes(x = tone_category, y = count, fill = factor(advancement))) +   geom_col(position = "dodge") +   labs(     title = "Contestant Advancement by Judge Feedback Tone",     x = "Judge Feedback Tone",     y = "Number of Contestants",     fill = "Advanced?"   ) +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("0" = "lightcoral", "1" = "lightgreen"),                     labels = c("0" = "Eliminated", "1" = "Advanced")) +   theme_minimal() judge_patterns <- idol_data %>%   filter(!is.na(gender)) %>%   group_by(judge_name, gender) %>%   summarize(     mean_tone = mean(tone, na.rm = TRUE),     n = n()   )  ggplot(judge_patterns, aes(x = judge_name, y = mean_tone, fill = gender)) +   geom_col(position = "dodge") +   labs(     title = "Judge Feedback Tone by Contestant Gender (by Judge)",     x = "Judge",     y = "Average Tone Score",     fill = "Contestant Gender"   ) +   ylim(0, 3) +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("Male" = "#1f77b4", "Female" = "#ff7f0e")) +   theme_minimal()

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Population: Everyone/everything want make claims (e.g., â€œTwitch chat messagesâ€) Sample: subset actually study (e.g., â€œ200 messages 10 streamsâ€) problem: canâ€™t study entire population (large, expensive). study sample infer whether patterns hold population.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Imagine flipping fair coin 10 times. might get 6 heads 4 tailsâ€”exactly 50/50. â€™s random chance. Now imagine sample 100 Twitch messages find 30% toxic. took different sample 100 messages, might get 28% 33%. variation called sampling variability. Key insight: Even â€™s real difference toxicity games, random sampling might make LOOK like â€™s difference. Inferential statistics help decide: â€œdifference real, just random noise?â€

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: p-value answers: â€œâ€™s really difference (null hypothesis true), often see difference big just random chance?â€ p = 0.03: â€œ3% time random chance produce result. Probably random!â€ p = 0.45: â€œ45% time random chance produce . Probably just noise.â€ threshold: convention, p < 0.05 (less 5%), say result statistically significantâ€”unlikely random.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: flip fair coin : - Probability heads = 0.5 (50%) - Probability tails = 0.5 (50%) roll fair six-sided die: - Probability rolling 3 = 1/6 â‰ˆ 0.167 (16.7%) Independence: coin doesnâ€™t â€œrememberâ€ previous flips. flip 50% chance. matters: Inferential tests assume samples independent (one observation doesnâ€™t influence another). violate (e.g., coding streamerâ€™s chat 20 times), tests invalid.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: null hypothesis assumption â€œnothing happening.â€ Example: H0H_0: â€œdifference toxicity rates Valorant Overwatch chat.â€ job researcher: try prove null wrong.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: p-value probability hypothesis true. â€™s probability observing data (something extreme) null hypothesis true. p < 0.05: data surprising null. reject H0H_0 (tentatively accept H1H_1). p â‰¥ 0.05: data surprising null. fail reject H0H_0 (donâ€™t â€œacceptâ€ ; just lack evidence ). Analogy: â€™re detective. null hypothesis â€œsuspect innocent.â€ p-value tells surprising evidence suspect innocent. â€™s surprising (p < 0.05), grounds charge (reject null). â€™s surprising, donâ€™t case.

what: Type I and Type II Errors
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Type Error (False Positive): Rejecting null â€™s actually true. Example: conclude Valorant toxic, difference just sampling error. Probability = Î± (significance level, typically 0.05). Type II Error (False Negative): Failing reject null â€™s actually false. Example: Valorant toxic, sample small detect . Probability = Î² (depends sample size effect size). trade-: Lower Î± (stricter threshold) reduces false positives increases false negatives. Science conventionally accepts 5% Type error rate (Î± = 0.05).

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Recall Chapter 1: null hypothesis â€œsacred flawâ€â€”universeâ€™s current story. Rejecting null means â€™ve forced universe admit story wrong adopt new one (alternative hypothesis). climax research narrative.

previous_headings: Overview > The Chi-Square Test of Independence
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Chi-Square compares observed frequencies (actually counted) expected frequencies (â€™d expect null true). Formula: Ï‡2=âˆ‘(Oâˆ’E)2E \chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O - E)^2}{E} : OO = observed frequency EE = expected frequency (calculated assuming independence) observed expected different, Ï‡2\chi^2 large â†’ small p-value â†’ reject H0H_0.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: CramÃ©râ€™s V measures strength association (0 = association, 1 = perfect association). Formula: V=Ï‡2nÃ—(kâˆ’1) V = \sqrt{\frac{\chi^2}{n \times (k-1)}} : nn = total sample size kk = smaller (rows, columns) Interpretation: V = 0.10: Small effect V = 0.30: Medium effect V = 0.50: Large effect R code: Output: Interpretation: association statistically significant relatively weak. title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables

[Describe pattern]. Example: Chi-Square test independence examined relationship game type (Valorant, Overwatch) message toxicity (Toxic, Neutral). relationship statistically significant, Ï‡Â²(1) = 12.34, p < .001, V = 0.18. Valorant chat messages likely toxic (32%) compared Overwatch messages (16%).

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: statistically significant result means pattern probably isnâ€™t due chance. meaningful? Example: find female streamersâ€™ chats 1% toxic messages male streamersâ€™ chats. Chi-Square significant (p = 0.04) sample huge (n = 10,000). Question: 1% matter real world? Probably . statistically significant practically trivial. Best practice: Report p-values (statistical significance) effect sizes (practical significance). Discuss whether effect large enough matter.

what: Misinterpretation 1: â€œp < 0.05 means the hypothesis is trueâ€
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Correction: p = 0.051 arbitrary. effect might real; just lack strong evidence. Donâ€™t treat 0.05 magic threshold.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Correction: Failing reject null doesnâ€™t mean null true. means donâ€™t enough evidence reject (possibly due small sample size weak effect).

what: Real Data: American Idol Judge Feedback Analysis
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Letâ€™s apply inferential tests answer research questions using cleaned American Idol dataset (Chapters 11-12).

previous_headings: Real Data: American Idol Judge Feedback Analysis
what: Research Question 1: Does Judge Tone Differ by Contestant Gender?
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Research Question: judges provide different feedback (tone) male vs.Â female contestants? Data Types: - Judge Tone: Continuous (0-3 scale) - Contestant Gender: Categorical (Male, Female) Appropriate Test: Independent samples t-test (comparing means continuous variable across 2 groups) Hypotheses: - H0H_0: Male female contestants receive equal average judge tone. - H1H_1: Male female contestants receive different average judge tone. Step 1: Descriptive Statistics Output: Interpretation: Male contestants receive slightly higher average tone (2.35 vs.Â 2.12), difference 0.23 points 0-3 scale. Step 2: Conduct t-test Output: Step 3: Calculate Effect Size (Cohenâ€™s d) Output: Step 4: Interpretation Reporting p-value = 0.063: Marginally non-significant (just 0.05 threshold) Cohenâ€™s d = 0.29: Small effect size Conclusion: â€œindependent samples t-test examined whether judge feedback tone differed contestant gender. males received slightly higher tone scores (M = 2.35, SD = 0.75) compared females (M = 2.12, SD = 0.81), difference marginally non-significant, t(143) = -1.87, p = .063, d = 0.29. effect size small. suggests judgesâ€™ feedback tone may systematically differ contestant gender, although larger sample might reveal genuine effect.â€
code: library(tidyverse)  idol_data <- read_csv("data_clean/idol_judge_feedback.csv")  # Summary by gender tone_by_gender <- idol_data %>%   filter(!is.na(gender), !is.na(tone)) %>%   group_by(gender) %>%   summarize(     mean_tone = mean(tone),     sd_tone = sd(tone),     n = n()   )  print(tone_by_gender) gender    mean_tone  sd_tone    n Female        2.12    0.81    54 Male          2.35    0.75    91 library(rstatix)  # For easier t-test reporting  # Prepare data (remove missing values) idol_clean <- idol_data %>%   filter(!is.na(gender), !is.na(tone))  # Run independent samples t-test t_test_result <- t_test(   idol_clean,   tone ~ gender,   var.equal = TRUE  # Assume equal variances )  print(t_test_result)  # Get detailed output with effect size t.test(idol_clean$tone[idol_clean$gender == "Female"],        idol_clean$tone[idol_clean$gender == "Male"],        var.equal = TRUE) t-test for independent samples    Welch Two Sample t-test  data:  tone by gender t = -1.87, df = 143, p-value = 0.063 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval:  -0.473  0.013 sample estimates: mean in group Female mean in group Male               2.12              2.35 library(effectsize)  cohens_d(idol_clean$tone ~ idol_clean$gender) Cohen's d |  95% CI         0.29 | [0.00, 0.58]

what: Research Question 2: Does Advancement Differ by Judge Feedback Tone?
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Research Question: positive judge feedback associated contestant advancement? Data Types: - Judge Tone: Categorical (Positive = tone â‰¥ 2 vs.Â Non-positive = tone < 2) - Advancement: Categorical (Advanced = 1 vs.Â Eliminated = 0) Appropriate Test: Chi-Square Test Independence (association two categorical variables) Hypotheses: - H0H_0: Judge tone advancement independent. - H1H_1: Judge tone advancement associated. Step 1: Create Contingency Table Output: Step 2: Run Chi-Square Test Output: Step 3: Calculate Effect Size (CramÃ©râ€™s V) Output: Step 4: Report Proportions Output: Step 5: Interpretation Reporting p-value = 7.2e-12: Highly significant (p < 0.001) CramÃ©râ€™s V = 0.49: Large effect size Advancement rates: 79.6% positive feedback vs.Â 28.3% non-positive feedback â€œChi-Square test independence examined whether judge feedback tone predicted contestant advancement. relationship highly significant, Ï‡Â²(1) = 46.78, p < .001, V = 0.49. Contestants receiving positive feedback advanced rate 79.6%, receiving non-positive feedback advanced rate 28.3%. large effect indicates judge feedback tone strong predictor contestant advancement.â€
code: # Create binary tone variable idol_chi <- idol_data %>%   filter(!is.na(tone), !is.na(advancement)) %>%   mutate(     tone_category = if_else(tone >= 2, "Positive", "Non-Positive"),     advancement_label = if_else(advancement == 1, "Advanced", "Eliminated")   )  # Contingency table contingency <- table(idol_chi$tone_category, idol_chi$advancement_label) print(contingency) Advanced Eliminated Non-Positive       15         38 Positive           82         21 chi_result <- chisq.test(contingency) chi_result Chi-squared test for independence  data:  contingency X-squared = 46.78, df = 1, p-value = 7.2e-12 cramers_v(contingency) CramÃ©r's V |  95% CI        0.49 | [0.37, 0.59] # Calculate proportions prop_advancement <- idol_chi %>%   group_by(tone_category) %>%   summarize(     advanced = sum(advancement_label == "Advanced"),     eliminated = sum(advancement_label == "Eliminated"),     total = n(),     advancement_rate = advanced / total   )  print(prop_advancement) tone_category  advanced eliminated total advancement_rate Non-Positive        15         38    53             0.283 Positive            82         21   103             0.796

what: Research Question 3: Do Multiple Judges Show Consistent Patterns?
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Research Question: judge feedback tone vary judge, tone-advancement relationship consistent across three judges? Data Types: - Judge: Categorical (3 categories: Katy, Luke, Lionel) - Judge Tone: Continuous (0-3 scale) Appropriate Test: One-Way ANOVA (comparing means across 3+ groups) Hypotheses: - H0H_0: three judges give equal average tone scores. - H1H_1: Judge tone scores differ among judges. Step 1: Descriptive Statistics Output: Step 2: Run One-Way ANOVA Output: Step 3: Calculate Effect Size (Eta-squared) Output: Step 4: Interpretation Reporting p-value = 0.511: significant (well 0.05 threshold) Eta-squared = 0.008: Negligible effect size Conclusion: â€œone-way ANOVA examined whether judge feedback tone differed among three judges (Katy Perry, Luke Bryan, Lionel Richie). analysis revealed significant differences tone across judges, F(2, 171) = 0.67, p = .511, Î·Â² = .008. three judges provided similar average tone scores (M = 2.15-2.28 0-3 scale), suggesting consistency feedback patterns across contestants.â€
code: tone_by_judge <- idol_data %>%   filter(!is.na(judge_name), !is.na(tone)) %>%   group_by(judge_name) %>%   summarize(     mean_tone = mean(tone),     sd_tone = sd(tone),     n = n()   )  print(tone_by_judge) judge_name   mean_tone  sd_tone    n Katy Perry       2.15    0.79    58 Lionel Richie    2.22    0.76    57 Luke Bryan       2.28    0.82    59 anova_result <- aov(tone ~ judge_name, data = idol_data) summary(anova_result) Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) judge_name   2  0.85   0.426   0.674  0.511 Residuals  171 108.34   0.634 library(effectsize)  eta_squared(anova_result) Eta2_partial |  95% CI          0.0078 | [0.00, 0.04]

text: H0H_0: two groups equal means: Î¼1=Î¼2\mu_1 = \mu_2 H1H_1: two groups different means: Î¼1â‰ Î¼2\mu_1 \neq \mu_2 (two-tailed) Î¼1>Î¼2\mu_1 > \mu_2 (one-tailed)

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: t-test compares difference group means variability within groups: t=Difference meansPooled standard error t = \frac{\text{Difference means}}{\text{Pooled standard error}} Intuition: groups far apart within-group variation small â†’ large t â†’ small p-value â†’ reject H0H_0 groups close together within-group variation large â†’ small t â†’ large p-value â†’ fail reject H0H_0

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Independent observations: Observations one group donâ€™t influence . Continuous data: dependent variable measured continuous scale (categories). Approximately normal: Data group roughly normally distributed (less critical large n). Equal variances (standard t-test): two groups similar variability. (Welchâ€™s t-test relaxes ).

what: Effect Size for t-Test: Cohenâ€™s d
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Cohenâ€™s d measures standardized difference means: d=M1âˆ’M2SDpooled d = \frac{M_1 - M_2}{SD_{\text{pooled}}} Interpretation: d = 0.20: Small effect d = 0.50: Medium effect d = 0.80: Large effect R code: Output: d = 0.32 (small medium effect)

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Use ANOVA (Analysis Variance) want compare means across three groups. Example research questions: toxicity rates differ across game genres (FPS, MOBA, MMO, Casual)? average engagement different morning, afternoon, evening streams? three social media platforms (TikTok, Instagram, YouTube) differ average video length?

what: Why Not Just Run Multiple t-Tests?
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: 4 groups, might compare: Group 1 vs.Â 2, 1 vs.Â 3, 1 vs.Â 4, 2 vs.Â 3, 2 vs.Â 4, 3 vs.Â 4. â€™s 6 t-tests. Problem: t-test 5% Type error rate. Running 6 tests inflates overall error rate ~26%! multiple comparisons problem. Solution: ANOVA controls overall Type error rate testing groups simultaneously.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: H0H_0: group means equal: Î¼1=Î¼2=Î¼3=...=Î¼k\mu_1 = \mu_2 = \mu_3 = ... = \mu_k H1H_1: least one group mean differs others.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: ANOVA partitions variance two sources: F=Variance groupsVariance within groups F = \frac{\text{Variance groups}}{\text{Variance within groups}} -group variance: different group means ? Within-group variance: much individuals vary within group? -group variance large compared within-group variance â†’ large F â†’ small p-value â†’ reject H0H_0.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Use Pearsonâ€™s r correlation want measure strength direction linear relationship two continuous variables. Example research questions: relationship hours streamed per week total monthly earnings? videos hashtags receive views? average viewer engagement correlated stream length? Note: Correlation imply causation. variables might influenced third variable, relationship might reverse.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: H0H_0: linear relationship: r=0r = 0 H1H_1: linear relationship: râ‰ 0r \neq 0

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Pearsonâ€™s r measures closely two variables co-vary: r=âˆ‘(xiâˆ’xâ€¾)(yiâˆ’yâ€¾)âˆ‘(xiâˆ’xâ€¾)2âˆ‘(yiâˆ’yâ€¾)2 r = \frac{\sum (x_i - \bar{x})(y_i - \bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum (x_i - \bar{x})^2 \sum (y_i - \bar{y})^2}} Interpretation: r = +1.0: Perfect positive correlation (x increases, y increases). r = 0.0: linear relationship. r = -1.0: Perfect negative correlation (x increases, y decreases). General guidelines: |r| = 0.10-0.29: Weak |r| = 0.30-0.49: Moderate |r| = 0.50-1.00: Strong

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: chapter introduced inferential statistics, hypothesis testing, toolkit foundational statistical tests: Foundational Concepts: - Inferential statistics assess whether sample patterns likely exist population just random noise - null hypothesis (Hâ‚€) assumes effect relationship; alternative hypothesis (Hâ‚) predicts effect - P-value: Probability observing data extreme null trueâ€”probability hypothesis true - Significance threshold: p < 0.05 conventionally means â€œreject nullâ€ (evidence effect) - Type error (Î± = 0.05): False positive (rejecting true null) - Type II error (Î²): False negative (failing reject false null) - Statistical significance â‰  practical significance: Always report effect sizes Choosing Tests Research Question: Chi-Square Test Independence: - Compares observed vs.Â expected frequencies categorical associations - Assumptions: Independent observations, expected counts â‰¥ 5 - Report: Ï‡Â²(df) = X.XX, p = .XXX, V = X.XX Independent Samples t-Test: - Compares means two groups - Assumptions: Independent observations, continuous data, normal distribution - Report: t(df) = X.XX, p = .XXX, d = X.XX One-Way ANOVA: - Compares means across three groups - Controls multiple comparisons problem - Use Tukey HSD post-hoc test identify groups differ - Report: F(dfâ‚, dfâ‚‚) = X.XX, p = .XXX, Î·Â² = X.XX Pearsonâ€™s Correlation: - Measures strength linear relationship continuous variables - r ranges -1 (perfect negative) +1 (perfect positive) - Always visualize correlations; correlation â‰  causation - Report: r(df) = X.XX, p = .XXX

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Alternative hypothesis (Hâ‚): Prediction effect relationship exists ANOVA (Analysis Variance): Inferential test comparing means across three groups Chi-Square test (Ï‡Â²): Inferential test association two categorical variables Cohenâ€™s d: Effect size t-test (0.2 = small, 0.5 = medium, 0.8 = large) Correlation (Pearsonâ€™s r): Measure linear relationship two continuous variables (-1 +1) CramÃ©râ€™s V: Effect size measure Chi-Square (0 1, indicating association strength) Degrees freedom (df): Number values free vary calculation Effect size: Magnitude effect, independent sample size Eta-squared (Î·Â²): Effect size ANOVA (0.01 = small, 0.06 = medium, 0.14 = large) Expected frequency: Count predicted null hypothesis true Fisherâ€™s Exact Test: Alternative Chi-Square small samples (expected counts < 5) F-statistic: Test statistic ANOVA (-group variance / within-group variance) Independent samples t-test: Inferential test comparing means two groups Inferential statistics: Statistical methods generalizing sample population Null hypothesis (Hâ‚€): Assumption effect relationship exists Observed frequency: Actual count cell contingency table P-value: Probability observing data extreme null true Practical significance: Whether effect large enough matter real world Post-hoc test (Tukey HSD): Follow-comparison significant ANOVA identify groups differ Regression: Statistical method predicting continuous outcome one predictors Statistical significance: Result unlikely due chance alone (typically p < 0.05) t-statistic: Test statistic t-test (difference means / standard error) Type error: False positive (rejecting true null hypothesis) Type II error: False negative (failing reject false null hypothesis)

text: Hook: Open compelling anecdote, statistic, question. Example: â€œ2023, Twitch averaged 2.5 million concurrent viewers daily, millions chat messages exchanged every hour. beneath emotes inside jokes lies darker pattern: toxic language, harassment, exclusionâ€”particularly competitive gaming spaces.â€ Literature Review (2-3 paragraphs): others discovered? gap study fills? Example: â€œPrior research documented toxicity multiplayer games (Gray, 2014; Consalvo, 2012), studies examine live-streaming contexts real-time moderation parasocial relationships complicate community dynamics. study addresses gap analyzing chat behavior across competitive casual game streams.â€ Research Question Hypothesis: State explicitly. Example: RQ: relationship game type (competitive vs.Â casual) prevalence toxic chat messages?
