text: Document every decision someone else replicate study.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Data Source: Archive, platform, date range, search terms. Example: â€œData collected 50 Twitch streams broadcast February 1-28, 2024. Streams selected top 100 channels average concurrent viewers TwitchTracker.com, stratified game genre (25 competitive FPS streams, 25 casual simulation/RPG streams).â€ Sample: Sampling frame, technique, final n. Example: â€œstream, 10 consecutive chat messages coded, yielding 500 total messages (250 competitive games, 250 casual games). Messages consisting solely emotes excluded.â€ Variables: Operational definitions (pull codebook, Chapter 9). Example: â€œMessage toxicity coded binary variable: Toxic (messages containing personal insults, slurs, threats) vs.Â Neutral (messages). See Appendix full codebook.â€ Reliability: Report pilot ICR (Chapter 10). Example: â€œTwo independent coders analyzed 50 pilot messages. Inter-coder reliability acceptable (Krippendorffâ€™s Î± = .76). Disagreements resolved discussion, codebook revised final coding.â€ Analytic Plan: statistical tests use? Example: â€œDescriptive statistics (frequencies, proportions) summarized distribution toxic messages. Chi-Square test independence assessed relationship game type toxicity.â€

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Present findings objectively. interpretation yetâ€”just report numbers say.

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Descriptive Statistics: Summarize sample. Example: â€œ500 coded messages, 120 (24%) classified toxic. Competitive game streams accounted 80 toxic messages (32% competitive messages), casual game streams accounted 40 toxic messages (16% casual messages).â€ Inferential Statistics: Report test results. Example: â€œChi-Square test revealed statistically significant association game type message toxicity, Ï‡Â²(1) = 12.34, p < .001, CramÃ©râ€™s V = 0.18. Competitive game chats exhibited higher rates toxicity compared casual game chats.â€ Tables Figures: Visualize key findings. Table 1: Toxicity Game Type Figure 1: Toxicity Rates Game Type

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Now interpret. findings mean?

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Summary Findings: Restate main result plain language. Example: â€œstudy found competitive game streams Twitch exhibit significantly higher rates toxic chat messages compared casual game streams, supporting hypothesis competitive contexts amplify hostile communication.â€ Theoretical Implications: Connect back theory (Chapter 5). Example: â€œfindings align Social Identity Theory (Tajfel & Turner, 1979), predicts competitive contexts heighten -group/-group dynamics, leading increased hostility toward perceived rivals. Competitive gaming may activate tribal identities, normalizing aggressive language.â€ Practical Implications: anyone care? Example: â€œPlatform designers moderators recognize competitive game streams may require stricter moderation policies automated toxicity detection tools. Streamers competitive genres may benefit training de-escalation techniques.â€ Limitations: transparent weaknesses. Example: â€œstudy analyzed top 100 Twitch channels, limiting generalizability smaller streamers. Additionally, coding relied manifest content (observable language) may missed subtle forms toxicity sarcasm coded language. Future research incorporate sentiment analysis examine longitudinal patterns.â€ Future Directions: comes next? Example: â€œFuture studies examine streamer responses toxic chat (bans, timeouts, verbal reprimands) affect subsequent toxicity rates. Additionally, comparative analysis across platforms (Twitch vs.Â YouTube Gaming) reveal whether platform affordances shape community norms.â€

what: American Idol Study: Full Report Outline
title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Title: â€œJudge Feedback Contestant Demographics American Idol: Content Analysis Bias Advancement Patternsâ€ Introduction American Idol, debuting 2002, become cultural phenomenon 500 episodes millions viewers. critical element show judgesâ€™ verbal feedback contestantsâ€”comments express evaluation, encouragement, critique. Prior research demonstrates judgesâ€™ feedback influences audience perception , likely, advancement outcomes (Shelly et al., 2015). However, whether judgesâ€™ feedback differs contestant demographic characteristics (gender, race/ethnicity) remains understudied context reality television talent competition. study addresses gap analyzing judge feedback tone relationship contestant advancement. Research Questions: 1. judges provide systematically different feedback (tone) contestants different genders? 2. positive judge feedback predict contestant advancement? 3. feedback patterns consistent across judges, individual judges show different patterns? Methods Data Source Sample: Data collected American Idol Seasons 20-23 (2022-2024). stratified random sample 60 episodes selected across three performance rounds: auditions (n=15), Hollywood week (n=14), live performance shows (n=31). stratification ensured representation across judging contexts, feedback differs elimination-heavy auditions emotionally charged live shows. episode features three judges (Katy Perry, Luke Bryan, Lionel Richie) providing feedback multiple contestants. Judge comments range brief acknowledgment (â€œNice!â€) detailed critiques lasting 30+ seconds. judge utterances directed specific contestant coded (n=174 judge comments 60-episode sample). Variables: Judge Feedback Tone (Ordinal, 0-3 scale): emotional valence judgeâ€™s feedback comment. - 3 = Strongly Positive (compliments ability, predicts success, uses superlatives) - 2 = Mildly Positive (appreciates effort, identifies strengths) - 1 = Neutral/Constructive (provides technical feedback without judgment) - 0 = Negative (expresses criticism, doubt, concern) Contestant Gender (Nominal): Contestantâ€™s gender identity presented introduction identified judgesâ€™ pronouns. Categories: Male, Female, Non-Binary. Contestant Race/Ethnicity (Nominal): Race/ethnicity coded contestant introduction statements appearance, including: White, Black, Latinx, Asian, Middle Eastern, Multiracial. Advancement (Binary): Whether contestant progressed next round (Yes=1, =0) based judge decision. Reliability Testing: pilot study two independent coders examined 3 episodes (approximately 40 judge comments). Inter-coder reliability assessed using Krippendorffâ€™s Alpha: Judge Tone (Î±=.82), Gender (Î±=.95), Advancement (Î±=1.00). acceptable levels (>0.70) indicated codebook clarity. codebook finalized applied full sample. Analysis Plan: Descriptive statistics (means, frequencies) summarized sample characteristics. independent samples t-test compared judge tone male female contestants. Chi-Square test examined association feedback tone advancement. one-way ANOVA assessed whether judges differed feedback patterns. Results Descriptive Statistics (n=174 judge comments): Mean judge tone across comments 2.18 (SD=0.79) 0-3 scale, indicating predominantly positive feedback. Contestants advanced rate 65.5% (114/174). Gender distribution: Male (52.3%), Female (31.0%), Non-Binary (6.9%), Unknown (9.8%). Research Question 1: Judge Tone Contestant Gender independent samples t-test examined whether judge tone differed contestant gender (excluding Unknown category, n=157). Female contestants (M=2.12, SD=0.81) received marginally lower tone scores male contestants (M=2.35, SD=0.75), difference marginally non-significant, t(143)=-1.87, p=.063, Cohenâ€™s d=0.29 (small effect). 95% confidence interval difference ranged -0.473 0.013. Research Question 2: Judge Tone Advancement Chi-Square test examined association judge feedback tone contestant advancement. Judge tone recoded binary: Positive (tone â‰¥ 2) vs.Â Non-Positive (tone < 2). relationship highly significant, Ï‡Â²(1)=46.78, p<.001, CramÃ©râ€™s V=0.49 (large effect). Contestants receiving positive feedback advanced rate 79.6% (82/103), receiving non-positive feedback advanced 28.3% (15/53). Research Question 3: Consistency Across Judges one-way ANOVA tested whether mean judge tone differed among three judges. Judges showed remarkably similar feedback patterns: Katy Perry (M=2.15, SD=0.79), Luke Bryan (M=2.28, SD=0.82), Lionel Richie (M=2.22, SD=0.76). differences statistically significant, F(2,171)=0.67, p=.511, Î·Â²=.008 (negligible effect). suggests judges apply consistent standards evaluating contestants. Discussion study examined judge feedback tone relationship contestant demographics advancement American Idol Seasons 20-23. Three key findings emerged. First, found significant differences judge tone contestant gender, though males received slightly higher tone scores females (difference 0.23 points). difference marginally non-significant (p=.063) small effect size (d=0.29), suggests judges may provide marginally warmer feedback male contestants, consistent prior literature documenting gender bias entertainment industries. However, modest effect size marginal significance indicate pattern warrants replication larger samples. Second, positive judge feedback strongly predicted contestant advancement. Contestants receiving positive feedback advanced rate 79.6%, compared 28.3% receiving non-positive feedback. large effect (V=0.49) suggests judge feedback tone powerful signal advancement likelihood, though causality inferred observational study. Third, three judges exhibited similar feedback patterns, suggesting institutional consistency evaluation standards. notable reality television, judgesâ€™ idiosyncratic personalities often drive viewer engagement. consistency may reflect producersâ€™ influence judge behavior genuine alignment evaluative criteria. Limitations: study focused recent seasons (2022-2024), limiting generalizability earlier Idol eras different judging panels production approaches. Race/ethnicity coding relied appearance assessment, introducing potential coder bias despite acceptable inter-rater reliability. Additionally, feedback tone measured verbal cues alone, missing non-verbal communication (facial expressions, body language) might convey different messages. Future research incorporate multi-modal analysis expand additional seasons international Idol franchises. Conclusions: judge feedback tone shows marginal differences contestant gender, strongly predicts advancement. consistency across judges suggests evaluation standards transcend individual judge personalities. Future research examine whether audience voting behavior aligns judge feedback investigate mechanisms feedback influences outcomes.

code: library(dplyr)  # Filter rows data %>% filter(toxicity == "Toxic") data %>% filter(viewers > 1000) data %>% filter(game == "Valorant" & uses_webcam == TRUE)  # Select columns data %>% select(id, game, toxicity) data %>% select(-coder_notes)  # Remove column  # Create/modify columns data %>% mutate(viewer_category = case_when(   viewers < 100 ~ "Small",   viewers < 1000 ~ "Medium",   viewers >= 1000 ~ "Large" ))  # Summarize data data %>% summarize(   total = n(),   avg_viewers = mean(viewers),   median_viewers = median(viewers) )  # Group and summarize data %>%   group_by(game) %>%   summarize(     total_streams = n(),     avg_viewers = mean(viewers),     toxic_rate = sum(toxicity == "Toxic") / n()   )  # Sort data data %>% arrange(viewers)  # Ascending data %>% arrange(desc(viewers))  # Descending  # Chain operations data %>%   filter(game %in% c("Valorant", "Overwatch")) %>%   mutate(is_toxic = ifelse(toxicity == "Toxic", 1, 0)) %>%   group_by(game) %>%   summarize(toxicity_rate = mean(is_toxic)) %>%   arrange(desc(toxicity_rate))

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
code: library(ggplot2)  # Bar chart ggplot(data, aes(x = category)) +   geom_bar(fill = "steelblue") +   labs(title = "Count by Category", x = "Category", y = "Count")  # Grouped bar chart ggplot(data, aes(x = game, fill = toxicity)) +   geom_bar(position = "dodge") +   labs(title = "Toxicity by Game", x = "Game", y = "Count")  # Stacked bar chart (proportions) ggplot(data, aes(x = game, fill = toxicity)) +   geom_bar(position = "fill") +   labs(title = "Toxicity Proportion by Game", y = "Proportion")  # Histogram ggplot(data, aes(x = viewers)) +   geom_histogram(bins = 30, fill = "coral", color = "black") +   labs(title = "Distribution of Viewers", x = "Viewers", y = "Frequency")  # Boxplot ggplot(data, aes(x = game, y = donations)) +   geom_boxplot(fill = "lightblue") +   labs(title = "Donations by Game", x = "Game", y = "Donations ($)")  # Scatterplot ggplot(data, aes(x = viewers, y = donations)) +   geom_point(color = "darkgreen") +   labs(title = "Viewers vs Donations", x = "Viewers", y = "Donations")  # Add best-fit line ggplot(data, aes(x = viewers, y = donations)) +   geom_point() +   geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "red") +   labs(title = "Viewers vs Donations")

code: # Chi-Square test chisq.test(data$game, data$toxicity)  # Save Chi-Square results chi_result <- chisq.test(data$game, data$toxicity) chi_result$statistic  # Chi-square value chi_result$p.value    # P-value chi_result$parameter  # Degrees of freedom  # Independent samples t-test t.test(viewers ~ uses_webcam, data = data)  # One-way ANOVA aov_result <- aov(viewers ~ game, data = data) summary(aov_result)  # Tukey post-hoc test TukeyHSD(aov_result)  # Pearson correlation cor.test(data$viewers, data$donations)  # Effect size for Chi-Square (CramÃ©r's V) library(effectsize) cramers_v(data$game, data$toxicity)  # Effect size for t-test (Cohen's d) cohens_d(viewers ~ uses_webcam, data = data)  # Effect size for ANOVA (Eta-squared) eta_squared(aov_result)

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Every project needs README explaining use . Template:
code: # Project Title  ## Author Your Name   Course: COM 400   Semester: Fall 2024  ## Research Question What is the relationship between streamer webcam use and viewer donations on Twitch?  ## Data Sources - Twitch API (via instructor-provided CSV) - Manual coding of 200 streams - Date range: September 1-30, 2024  ## File Organization - `data/raw/` - Original API output - `data/processed/` - Cleaned and coded data - `code/` - Analysis scripts (run in numbered order) - `output/` - Figures and tables for final report  ## How to Reproduce This Analysis 1. Open `project.Rproj` in RStudio 2. Install required packages: `install.packages(c("tidyverse", "effectsize"))` 3. Run scripts in order:    - `01_data_cleaning.R`    - `02_descriptives.R`    - `03_inferential.R` 4. Final report: Render `analysis_report.qmd`  ## Notes - Inter-coder reliability (Krippendorff's Alpha) = .87 - One stream removed due to moderation issues (ID: stream_045) - See `documents/codebook.qmd` for variable definitions  ## Contact your.email@example.com

code: # Data Documentation  ## raw/chat_logs.csv - **Source**: Twitch API via instructor (Dr. Smith) - **Date collected**: September 1-30, 2024 - **Rows**: 10,000 messages from 50 streams - **Columns**:   - `message_id`: Unique identifier (1-10000)   - `stream_id`: Stream identifier (stream_001 - stream_050)   - `timestamp`: UTC timestamp   - `username`: Anonymized (user_001 - user_XXXX)   - `message_text`: Raw chat message   - `emotes`: Twitch emotes used (comma-separated)  ## processed/cleaned_data.csv - **Created**: October 15, 2024 - **Script**: `code/01_data_cleaning.R` - **Changes from raw**:   - Removed 237 bot messages (username pattern: "^nightbot|^streamelements")   - Standardized game names (see codebook)   - Added `toxicity` column (hand-coded)   - Added `message_length` (character count)  ## processed/coding_complete.csv - **Created**: October 25, 2024 - **Coders**: Yourself, Partner Name - **ICR**: Î± = .87 - **New variables**:   - `toxicity`: (Neutral / Toxic / Unclear)   - `target`: (Streamer / Other_user / Game / None)   - `coder_id`: (coder_1 / coder_2)

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables

title: Welcome to From Vibes to Variables
text: Run checks analysis:
code: # 1. Check for duplicates sum(duplicated(data$message_id))  # Should be 0  # 2. Check for missing values summary(data)  # Look for NA counts  # 3. Check variable ranges summary(data$viewers)  # Min/Max reasonable?  # 4. Check category consistency table(data$toxicity)  # Only expected values?  # 5. Check sample size nrow(data)  # Matches research plan?  # 6. Check data types str(data)  # Characters vs. factors vs. numeric correct?
